content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic I was wondering, is there a list/document somewhere of all the IndieAuth features that are implemented in yarn.social? I try using my URL as a micropub endpoint but get errors whenever I do that, and it's unclear to me where to look to see if yarn.social is a valid micropub endpoint. It'd be good to know what it can/can't do because personally I'd like to have a fully-compliant IndieWeb setup and use yarn for as much of that as possible.

@abucci@anthony.buc.ci Probably or our implementation is out of date compared to the spec? ü§î

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @darch Looking great! :-)

@bender@twtxt.net Oh I missed that! üò±

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic I was wondering, is there a list/document somewhere of all the IndieAuth features that are implemented in yarn.social? I try using my URL as a micropub endpoint but get errors whenever I do that, and it's unclear to me where to look to see if yarn.social is a valid micropub endpoint. It'd be good to know what it can/can't do because personally I'd like to have a fully-compliant IndieWeb setup and use yarn for as much of that as possible.

@abucci@anthony.buc.ci I‚Äôm a bit surprised to see as much missing there as the tool reports. IndieAuth should be there as well as the token_endpoint and various other bits. Hmmm. Also WebSub should also be there as well, as all Pods uses WebSub between each other (recently promoted this feature flag).

@darch@neotxt.dk What makes you say that? ü§î

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª So... What a crazy ass world we live in! ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Any of you (I know @deebs does) remember when Minecraft was a kids games for kids and created by this awesome guy and was open source (I believe)? ü§î -- That is until he sold it to Microsoft (who bought it for stupid amounts of money). What did Microsoft go and do with it? That's right kids! üòÖ They forced everyone old and new ever wanting to play the game to have a "Microsoft" account. ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è -- So my daughter has been wanting to play for some years now, I've said "No". But she's a bit older now, so its getting harder to say no. -- So she now has an account. But in order to protect her real identity and her email email address (I'm her father, of course I'm going to set her up in this stupid ass digital world properly ü§£); I had to 1) buy a random domain name 2) delegate it to Cloudflare 3) Setup Email routing. All this so I could setup basically "junk" / "throwaway" email addresses and create an account with "basically garbage data". ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

@bender Its actually even worse than that. Yes I went through a few extra steps, because I wanted to be in control of the ‚Äúthrow away email‚Äù as well. However, as it turns out, Microsoft basically force you to have a Microsoft Live Account, which (btw) gives you access to Teams, Outlook (and their own Email?!), Office, etc, etc. It‚Äôs not just an account for Minecraft ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è ‚Äì Then when you finally sign-in, you get to create your actual Mincecraft Username ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Sidequestion: currently I am running a TiddlyWiki for myself with private and public tagged posts. The intention was, to make non-private tiddlers (posts) public at one point in the future. Now I have found https://github.com/usememos/memos whis looks really nice. If I find out how to skin it a bit to have wider text, I shortly thought about switching over. No InterWiki Links so, but that is doable by linking manually.

@carsten@yarn.zn80.net This looks interesting though üëå

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @all Why is that, the yarn kicks me out of logged in status after like 30 minutes of inactivity? That is a really short timeout for a session, isn't it?

@carsten@yarn.zn80.net Pretty sure by default memory backed sessions are 1hr. This is of course configurable. üòÜ You can also tick yue ‚ÄúRemember Me‚Äù box to have a database backed session that by default is 10d. üëå

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @movq When I quitted WhatsApp I went to Signal and this works really nice. You also have a native Desktop App and no outages so far. You can create bots for automation, which is a bit easier with Telegram, but hey, you can do that (Octoprint I hear to calling for filament change :-))

@carsten@yarn.zn80.net This ease of use is also just as important for ease of operations. Which reminds me‚Ä¶ Btw‚Ä¶ Have you tried Salty Chat at all yet? ü§î I know its not ‚Äúprime time‚Äù ready for the masses yet (lacking a decent Mobile App), but feedback from folks like you even at this stage is highly valuable üëå

Signal‚Ñ¢ is great, I use it everywhere currently, most people I communicate with are on Signal. Only downside is it is centralised and requires a phone number.

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Oki doki. Now that I have not used my Twitter account for quite some time and have been posting to https://nrw.social/cblte I am pleased with the feedback, the conversations, the reactions, and discussions I already had. Twitter was, even in the beginning, not that nice. Too many people, too many things, and if you ask something, even with 400 followers, it does not get seen. But I also should interact here a bit more often, right? But which "universe" to be used for what?

@carsten@yarn.zn80.net Hmmm ü§î I actually thought I had the concept/idea quite clear in my head, but I can‚Äôt seem to articulate it today ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è ‚Äì In any case, the idea would be to have a 2-way bridge between Twtxt and ActivityPub, we can already follow most Mastodon users for example (feeds.twtxt.net supports this), but its only 1-way üò¢ ‚Äì Also the ActivityPub protocol itself is quite challenge to use and wrap your head around ü§Ø

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic I have to confess, I never really had a look at Salty. ü§î Is it ready for ‚Äúprime time‚Äù? I.e., usable by non-tech users, Android and iOS client, easy upload of images and videos, ‚Ä¶ ?

No sadly not yet üò¢ Needs a far better mobile app üëå

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Oki doki. Now that I have not used my Twitter account for quite some time and have been posting to https://nrw.social/cblte I am pleased with the feedback, the conversations, the reactions, and discussions I already had. Twitter was, even in the beginning, not that nice. Too many people, too many things, and if you ask something, even with 400 followers, it does not get seen.
